texts.shortText: Forms extensive bunches of upright yellow-brown stems emerging from a mat of intertwining root-like rhizomes. Stems about 3-4 mm diameter, initially unbranched, but soon develop flattened alternate lateral branches. Older branches constricted at their bases.
Upright stems reaching in height, stems about 3 mm wide. Single individual can form dense mats up to 1 m in diameter.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Has a surprisingly limited distribution from only about the Cape Peninsula to Cape Agulhas (with a couple isolated records beyond).

An interesting species in that it forms extensive colonies that can dominate considerable areas of the lower intertidal, but nevertheless has an extremely limited geographic range. Holdfasts appear to be long lived, but give rise to new generations of upright stems each year. The unusual and equally range-restricted amphipod Macropisthopus stebbingi, which has an enormously swollen last pair of legs, appears to have an obligate association with this alga, weaving small nests in the branches between the main stem and its lateral branches.

Edible and has a pleasant, crunchy texture and nutty taste when eaten raw.
Dominance achieved primarily by vegetate spread of the rhizomes. Individuals are of a single sex and reproductive organs are borne in two tows or conceptacles on either side of lateral stems.

Can be confused with Upright wrack Bifurcariopsis capensis (also because of similarly long generic name!) but that species emerges from a single disc-shaped holdfast and has a more bush-like form with sparser, tougher, more woody branches.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 386).

Molinari-Novoa, EA & Guiry, MD (2021). Nomenclatural notes on algae. V. New names for various algal taxa, mostly at the species rank. Notulae Algarum, 184, 1-17.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 198).
